metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of hydrometeorological observation network (No.3 runoff observation system of Railway bridge on the Heihe River, 2013)
metadata.description:
The No. 3 hydrological section is located at Railway Heihe River Bridge (100.430° E, 39.043° N, 1443 m) in the midstream of the Heihe River Basin, Zhangye city, Gansu Province. The dataset contains observations recorded by the No.3 hydrological section from 14 June, 2012, to 31 December, 2013. The width of this section is 50 meters. The water level was measured using an SR50 ultrasonic range and the discharge was measured using cross-section reconnaissance by the StreamPro ADCP. The dataset includes the following parameter: water level (recorded every 30 minutes) and discharge. The missing and incorrect (outside the normal range) data were replaced with -6999.
For more information, please refer to Li et al. (2013) (for hydrometeorological observation network or sites information), He et al. (2016) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What does 'eco-hydrological sensor network' entail in the context of data collection for oasis-desert systems?
Definition.Answer: An eco-hydrological sensor network involves deploying an array of sensors to monitor soil moisture, leaf area index, and other relevant parameters to understand the eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems. This network is part of a larger observation system designed to capture the interactions between ecological and hydrological components.

Definition.Question: How are 'hierarchically nested scales' utilized in hydrometeorological observations?
Definition.Answer: Hierarchically nested scales are used in hydrometeorological observations to arrange instruments in a structured manner that captures processes at multiple scales. For example, during the HiWATER experiment, instruments were placed in an oasis-desert system on various scales, including superstations and smaller meteorological stations to monitor different environmental landscapes, allowing for comprehensive data collection across spatial scales.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for hydrometeorological observations during the HiWATER experiment compare to those used in the oasis–desert system study?
Comparison.Answer: The HiWATER experiment utilized a hierarchically nested scale approach with instruments like eddy covariance towers and automatic meteorological stations, focusing on multiscale eco-hydrological processes. In contrast, the oasis–desert system study employed long-term observations with eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, focusing on energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, supplemented with hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges faced in obtaining multiscale observations in the HiWATER experiment compare to those in maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems for sustainable development?
Comparison.Answer: The HiWATER experiment's challenge is the poor availability of multiscale observations for eco-hydrological processes, requiring sophisticated instrumentation. Conversely, the oasis–desert system's challenge involves managing ecological degradation and maintaining energy, water vapor, and carbon balance, requiring long-term, comprehensive datasets for ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies could be employed to address the challenges of poor availability of multiscale observations in eco-hydrological systems?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of hierarchically nested scales for instrumentation, as seen in the HiWATER experiment, can help address the challenge of poor multiscale observation availability. Implementing a sparse network, superstations, EC towers, automatic meteorological stations, and conducting airborne remote sensing missions are effective methodologies to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes.

Interpretation.Question: How can data processing and quality control procedures be enhanced to ensure accurate data representation in eco-hydrological studies?
Interpretation.Answer: Enhancing data processing and quality control can involve meticulous procedures such as sensor calibration, careful data collection, comprehensive data processing, and diligent dataset generation. Ensuring these procedures are in place can result in high-quality and reliable data for eco-hydrological studies.

Interpretation.Question: What strategies might be used to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems to achieve sustainable development goals?
Interpretation.Answer: Strategies to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems could include long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange. Observing hydrometeorological data, vegetation, and soil parameters, as well as understanding oasis-desert interactions, are critical to supporting ecological security and sustainable development in these areas.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are hydrometeorological data and turbulent fluxes collected and processed in oasis-desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In oasis-desert systems, hydrometeorological data including radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles are collected by automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period. Turbulent flux data are acquired using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The data processing involves steps of data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.

Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In eco-hydrological research, the procedure for quality control and calibration of observational data involves sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. This ensures that all observational data are carefully managed to maintain accuracy and reliability.

Enablement.Question: What instrumentation and observational techniques enable the collection of multiscale and multidisciplinary eco-hydrological data in arid and semi-arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The instrumentation for multiscale and multidisciplinary data collection in arid and semi-arid regions involves hierarchically nested scales with a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. Additional techniques include a sparse network to investigate oasis-desert interactions, a superstation within the oasis, EC towers, automatic meteorological stations in various landscapes, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer.

Enablement.Question: How do long-term observational datasets of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes enable the understanding of oasis-desert interactions and support ecological stability?
Enablement.Answer: Long-term observational datasets of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes provide critical quantitative data that help understand oasis-desert interactions. These datasets, obtained through eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, automatic weather stations, and additional hydrometeorological observations, support the recognition of ecological stability and socioeconomic development in oasis regions by offering insights into the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes.
